claim.text: Philadelphia's Green City, Clean Waters plan, launched in 2011
claim.claim: Philadelphia's Green City, Clean Waters plan was launched in 2011

results.summary: Philadelphia's Green City, Clean Waters plan was indeed launched in 2011.
results.detail: The Green City, Clean Waters initiative is Philadelphia's 25-year plan to manage stormwater through green infrastructure. It was approved by the EPA and Pennsylvania DEP in 2011, making it one of the first major U.S. city plans to rely primarily on green infrastructure for combined sewer overflow compliance. The plan was officially adopted following a consent order agreement.
sources: Philadelphia Water Department official program documentation
EPA combined sewer overflow program records

claim.text: This is the same principle Alexander recognized in his Green Streets pattern (51)
claim.claim: Christopher Alexander's 'A Pattern Language' contains a pattern called 'Green Streets' numbered 51

results.summary: Pattern 51 in Christopher Alexander's 'A Pattern Language' is indeed 'Green Streets'.
results.detail: Christopher Alexander's 'A Pattern Language' (1977) contains 253 patterns numbered 1-253. Pattern 51 is titled 'Green Streets' and addresses the relationship between streets and trees/greenery, arguing that streets should be lined with trees and have green space integrated into them. This is a well-documented pattern in Alexander's seminal work on architectural and urban design patterns.
sources: Christopher Alexander, Sara Ishikawa, Murray Silverstein, 'A Pattern Language: Towns, Buildings, Construction' (1977), Oxford University Press
